text: Great, thanks Teddy, how about around 2pm today? We can introduce ourselves, and find out what would the most helpful things I can offer through mentoring
Sounds good to me!
Hi Caroline, I am about now :slightly_smiling_face:
Hey Teddy, lets chat about what you'd like to get through mentoring, you mentioned you'd like to know more about how to meet industry standards for when you graduate?
Could you unpack that a little more, are there any things you've heard that have made you think you won't be at industry standard?
Yes, sometimes I feel here at uni we aren't always explained exactly what industries want to see from us, other than a "variety of work showcasing our skills", which is a bit vague
Yes thats a little vague. So what do you know about the VFX and animation industry already? You know about routes in through being a runner? Is that the type of route you'd like to take after Uni?

Yeah, I've been to a few talks led by industry speakers (which is how I learnt about this), and those have been helpful with guidelines on getting into the industry. I personally just have anxieties about leaving education and going into industry, as sometimes I am not happy with the work I produce compared to other people I know, and sometimes have no idea what I'd like to do as a job
OK, that sounds very normal. Its a transition from uni to industry. And its quite normal to not know exactly what you'd like to do as a job. There are lots of options.
Can I ask where you're based at the moment? I'm just wondering what type of internship opportunities might be near you
I am in Stoke on Trent in Staffs uni, and I'm happy to travel a bit as we have pretty good train connections here
I did also think of going into pre-production work like concept design or something similar
Ok great, so did you attend the Access VFX stoke event a couple of weeks ago?
Yep that was where I heard about this mentor programme
Awesome!
So you said you've also thought about pre-production like concept design, what do you find appealing about that?

I guess maybe it's a bit less animation, more just drawing :grin: It's always interested me and I've been curious about it, I guess I just felt my skills up to this point maybe weren't as relevant for it almost

I'm trying to piece together an image of where you are at the moment and then we can draw up some things we can explore through the mentoring which might be useful to build your confidence in getting into the film industry.
Okay

So you're interested in concept design because its more drawing, but what do you mean by 'my skills up to this point weren't as relevant'? What do you think your skills are? What do you feel are your strengths?

I'd been pretty indecisive with what I wanted to do out of school, and ended up doing a fashion course at college for 2 years, and at the end of that still being pretty unsure. My tutors encouraged me to look more at illustration-based courses for university, as they and I accepted fashion maybe wasn't my thing. I was looking at illustration courses, but at a uni creative industries convention in London, fell into talking with the animation tutor at Staffs, who convinced me to go with animation rather than illustration (he's very convincing). So I've kind of been dotting around here and there - I have art/design skills from both college and uni, and have been developing story-telling and animating skills in the last year at uni
Wow that's really interesting
Yeah, so I feel I've got a random mixed bag of skills that maybe need expanding i guess?
Well, this might be a good time for me to say  a bit about what I can offer as a mentor and then lets see which topics would be most helpful to explore
Okay!

I see my role as a mentor as helping you learn more about yourself through our conversations, I have been a counsellor and a careers advisor. Now I'm working for Escape Studios who teach VFX, animation and game art, so I've learnt a lot about those industries, but i'm not an artist, so I won't be able to give you detailed feedback on your work.

What I think might be interesting to explore is what elements of your course are you enjoying and where are you not? Which might give you some direction on career paths to explore more. Most people don't find their dream job and stay in it for their whole career. For most of us, its a journey of trying something for a while, learning what we like about it and what we don't and using that to shape our next project or next job
So you've got a great opportunity right now to test the water of a few different career paths, reflect on what you like about them and what you don't

So from what you've said so far, its interesting that you started out interested in illustration, and you've mentioned you like the idea of concept design because its more drawing. Is there much drawing on your course or is it mostly computer based work?
Does that sound like something helpful to discuss? You can say if that's not what you were expecting. That's what this first chat is all about. :+1:
Okay, that makes sense, and yes it's definitely helpful! Sorry I went quiet, but I am definitely thinking this will help
Great, well I've got to go in a few minutes, so shall we wrap up with some things you could explore over the next week and arrange time to both be online again next week. Are Friday's good for you?

There is some drawing on our course, more so last year than this year, but next semester I am doing a module on experimental animation which I'm thinking will be more free and expressive. We do a fair amount of computer work, but at the same time it's allowed us to do digital art. Yes Fridays this sort of time are good for me - I usually have class in the morning but 2pm is good

Interesting, experimental animation sounds fun! I think it would be helpful if you could have a think over the next week about the hard skills you're learning on the course, like life drawing, rigging, sculpting (for example) and give them two scores from 1-5 - first for how well you're doing, like the grades you're getting and one for how much you enjoy it/how easy you find it to put in the hours. Often when you loose track of time when you're doing something tells you how much you enjoy doing it. And then think of a list of soft skills, like listening, cooperating with others, giving feedback, and give yourself a score from 1-5 of how good you are. I can try to find a list of the soft skills which might help you.
But don't worry if you don't have time to work on it before next Friday, we could run through it together if that's easier.
I will definitely make an effort to get that for you :slightly_smiling_face:

We can then look at the hard and soft skills you're best at and see if that helps highlight some areas to explore or areas to improve. And sometimes, just increasing your own self awareness can boost your confidence about getting into the industry. I'm sure you have more skills than you realise!
Aha thank you
Great to chat today, and look forward to catching up next week. I'll have a look for lists of hard and soft skills to chat about next week
Talk to you next week!
